results.name: Number of solutions to c(1)*prime(2) + ... + c(2n-1)*prime(2n) = -1, where c(i) = +-1 for i > 1, c(1) = 1.
comment: There cannot be a solution for an even number of terms on the l.h.s. because all terms are odd but the r.h.s. is odd, too.
link: Alois P. Heinz, Table of n, a(n) for n = 1..300
example: a(1) = a(2) = 0 because prime(2) and prime(2) +- prime(3) +- prime(4) are always different from -1.
a(3) = 1 because the solution prime(2) + prime(3) - prime(4) + prime(5) - prime(6) = -1 is the only one involving prime(2) through prime(6).
mathematica: b[n_, i_] := b[n, i] = If[n > s[i], 0, If[i == 2, 1, b[Abs[n-Prime[i]], i-1] + b[n+Prime[i], i-1]]];

program: (PARI) A261062(n,rhs=-1,firstprime=2)={rhs-=prime(firstprime);my(p=vector(2*n-2+bittest(rhs,0),i,prime(i+firstprime)));sum(i=1,2^#p-1,sum(j=1,#p,(-1)^bittest(i,j-1)*p[j])==rhs)} \\ For illustrative purpose; too slow for n >> 10.
